metadata.title: Catalytic styrene combustion over Pt/ZSM-5 Catalysts: Elucidating the deactivation mechanism induced by surface acid sites

Catalytic oxidation plays a pivotal role in styrene elimination, yet the development of highly active and robust catalysts remains a challenge. This work aims to elucidate the mechanisms underlying styrene oxidation and catalyst deactivation over the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst. The Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with low Si/Al ratio and high surface acidity leads to generation of small Pt particle, the initial activity of the catalyst varies in a volcanic curve with the size of Pt particles. Notably, the Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalyst with Pt particle size of 3.3 nm exhibits the highest reaction rate of 1.6 µmol gPt −1 s−1 at 100 °C. However, the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts undergo significant deactivation at their T80 (the temperature styrene conversion of 80 %). Through comprehensive characterizations and detailed mechanistic studies, it has been observed that intermediates from styrene oxidation accumulate heavily on the catalyst, especially for the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with high acidity. Improving the reaction temperature could inhibit the deactivation which is dependent on the surface acidity of Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst. For instance, the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts remains high activity when reaction is operated at T99+30, whereas a substantially higher reaction temperature (T99+80) is required for both Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalysts to counteract deactivation. Our primary results provide insights to develop effective and robust catalyst for styrene oxidation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pt@ZSM-5 Styrene complete oxidation Catalyst deactivation Surface acidity Carbon deposition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Styrene as one of the 50 largest volume industrial raw materials in the world is widely used in synthetic rubber, plastics, resins, pharmaceuticals and other industries, and it is still produced at a high rate of millions of tons per year [1,2]. However, the use of such large amount of styrene also brings a serious environmental problem, because the release of massive styrene exhaust gas poses a great threat to human health and ecological environment [4,5]. Styrene would seriously damage our respiratory system and central nervous system even at low concentrations, owing to styrene being easily absorbed by human through respiratory tract, skin and digestive tract. Therefore, styrene is regarded as one of the priority environmental toxic pollutants, and there is an urgent need to remove styrene exhaust gas due to the strict legislations published for protecting environment. Numerous technologies have been developed to control the emission of this troublesome substance, including adsorption, thermal combustion, catalytic combustion, low-temperature plasma, and photocatalytic oxidation [6–9]. Among them, catalytic combustion is considered to be one of the most promising techniques for eliminating styrene exhaust gas, which directly oxidizes deleterious styrene into harmless CO2 and H2O at relatively low temperature [10]. It should be pointed out that the catalysts employed for styrene combustion is decisive to the elimination efficiency, thus understanding the reaction mechanism and active sites on catalyst surface is vital for designing effective catalysts. The catalysts used for VOCs combustion commonly include two categories: transition metal oxide catalysts (CuO, CeO2, MnOx, etc.) and supported noble metal catalysts (Pt, Pd) [11-15]. Although numerous previous works studied the VOCs combustion over transition metal oxide catalysts because of their accessibility and low cost, their low thermal stabilities seriously limited the wide industrial applications [16-18]. Due to the high activity and thermal stability, noble metal catalysts are recognized as more suitable ones and widely employed in the field of VOCs combustion. In particularly, Pt based catalysts have drawn more and more attentions due to price advantage compared to Pd metal. In the previous research, it is found that there are many factors significantly affecting the performances of Pt based catalysts: nature of Pt active sites (particles sizes, chemical state, morphologies), support properties, promoters addition, etc. [19-21]. Thus, precisely regulating the particle size of Pt is often employed to improve the activity of Pt based catalysts. For instance, Ge et al. found that the size of Pt nanoparticles on CeO2 (100) significantly affects the charge of Pt specie, which is closely related to the catalytic performance of catalyst [22]. Many supports have been used for loading Pt catalysts, including zeolites (ZSM-5, HY, etc.) and metal oxides (ZrO2, Al2O3, CeO2, etc.). And it is found that surface acidity of support often remarkably affects the nature of Pt active sites, such as strong acid support benefits to stabilize the metallic Pt species under oxidation atmosphere. Due to the high specific surface area, uniform porous structure and abundant acid sites on surface, ZMS-5 zeolites are often employed to support Pt catalyst for catalytic oxidation reaction. Wang et al. found the strong acidity of ZSM-5 also benefits to the small size of Pt particle generation, which enhances the catalytic activity [23]. Besides catalytic activity, another question is also necessary to be considered, for instance, carbon deposition is considered as one of the significant threats to zeolites supported Pt catalysts, and carbon deposition preferred to occur at the acid sites on the catalyst surface. In particularly, unstable styrene easily aggregates on the catalyst surface, leading to significant carbon deposition. Thus, there is a great challenge in developing a highly active and durable catalyst for styrene combustion, which seriously limited the application of ZSM-5 supported Pt catalysts. However, there are still few works on the deactivation mechanism of catalyst for styrene oxidation. Herein, we conducted the studies of styrene combustion over a series of Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts with different surface acidity (different Si/Al ratio). Combined with the detailed characterizations of TEM, NH3-TPD and styrene oxidation in-suit FTIR, etc., the relationship between catalytic activity and Pt nanoparticles size has been investigated. More importantly, to clearly understand the deactivation mechanism of Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst, this work focused on studying the carbon deposition pathway. It is found that surface acid sites benefits to highly disperse the Pt species and the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with suitable small size of Pt particle exhibits the high initial reaction rate. However, the styrene oxidation intermediates (benzaldehyde, maleic anhydride, etc.) easily accumulated on the catalyst surface with high acidity. The higher the surface acidity of the catalyst, the more difficult it is to remove these reaction intermediates. To avoid deactivation caused by carbon deposition, the catalyst with high surface acidity needs to be carried out at a reaction temperature much higher than T99. Our primary work provides profound insights into surface acidity influences on catalytic activity and deactivation mechanism caused by carbon deposition. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis A series of commercial ZSM-5 supports with varying Si/Al ratios (Si/Al= 18, 40, 800 and 1200) were obtained from Shandong Dengzhuo Chemical Co., Ltd., China. Pt(NO3)2 solution as Pt precursor was purchased from Shanghai Tuosi Chemical Co., Ltd., China. The typical impregnation method was employed for preparation of a series of Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts with 1 wt.% Pt loading. In a typical procedure, the 1.00 g of ZSM-5 support was immersed into Pt(NO3)2 aqueous solution (5 mL, 0.002 g ml−1) for 2 h, followed by evaporation and drying at 100 °C for 3 h. Afterwards, the solid was calcined in a muffle furnace at 600 °C for 4 h. Consequently, a series of Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts with different Si/Al ratios were synthesized and designated as Pt@ZSM-5-x, where ‘x’ represents the Si/Al ratio of the ZSM-5 zeolite. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using an X-ray diffractometer, employing Cu Kα radiation (Bruker D8, 40 kV, 40 mA). The scan speed was set at 12° min−1 across a range of 2θ from 5 to 90° The Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface areas of the synthesized catalysts were measured through N2 adsorption at −196 °C on a BK 200C apparatus. Prior to the analysis, the catalyst underwent degassing for four hours at 100 °C to eliminate any residual substances. To analyze carbon deposition content, the thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) was carried on a NETZSCH STA 449F3 analyzer from 30 to 800 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 under air flow. Prior to the test, the sample was dried at 100 °C to remove the adsorbed substance such as water, etc. The surface acidity of the catalyst was analyzed using a home-made laboratory apparatus. Typically, 100 mg of the catalyst was introduced into the apparatus and pre-treated under a nitrogen flow (20 mL min−1) at a temperature of 300 °C for a duration of 30 min, subsequently cooling to 50 °C. Following this, a pure ammonia flow (30 mL min−1) was directed through the catalyst bed for a period of 10 min. This was followed by a nitrogen gas flow (20 mL min−1) for 0.5 h to eliminate any residual gaseous ammonia and physically adsorbed ammonia on the catalyst surface. Finally, the catalyst bed was heated from 40 to 700 °C in a high-purity helium flow (20 mL min−1) to desorb the ammonia that had been chemisorbed on acid sites. Concurrently, the ammonia signal was recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The dispersion of Pt was ascertained through CO chemisorption, utilizing a BELCAT II analyzer. Prior to the experiment, the catalyst underwent reduction under a gas flow mixture (5 % H2/N2 balanced, 30 mL min−1) at a temperature of 150 °C for one hour. Following this, a pulsed flow of CO mixture (5 % CO/N2 balanced) was introduced into the analyzer to measure the uptake of CO chemisorption. The dispersion of Pt was subsequently calculated based on the uptake of CO, assuming a CO:Pt ratio of 1:1. In-situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectra (DRIFTS) of styrene oxidation were conducted using a Thermal Fischer Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer, equipped with a MCT detector and a PIKE DRIFT accessory. Prior to the experiment, the catalyst placed in the PIKE DRIFT accessory was subjected to treatment in an atmosphere of 10 % O2 + 90 % N2 at 300 °C for 30 min to eliminate residuals on the catalyst surface. Background spectra were subsequently recorded. Following this, a mixture flow (styrene/air balanced, at 30 mL min−1) was introduced into the apparatus for 30 min at 50 °C. This was followed by a pure N2 flow (30 mL min−1) for another 30 min, after which the spectra were recorded. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of CO chemisorption were measured on a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector and a PIKE DRIFT accessory for the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts. Prior to the test, a certain amount of catalyst was put into a cell and was pre-treated in a O2 mixture flow (30 mL min−1, 10 % O2 + 90 % N2) at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to 30 °C in a N2 flow (30 mL min−1). Subsequently, the sample was reduced in a high purity H2 flow (30 mL min−1) at 300 °C for another 1 h. After it was cooled down to 30 °C, a mixture of 5% CO in He (30 mL min−1) was introduced for 30 min. After purge with N2 (30 mL min−1) for 1 h, the spectrum was recorded at 30 °C. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The styrene oxidation activities of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts were measured using a home-made reactor. In typical, the catalyst (60–80 mesh, 50 mg) was introduced into a quartz wool-secured reactor. A quartz bubbler, filled with styrene liquid, was positioned in a water bath at 30 °C. An air flow (5 mL min−1) was directed through the bubbler to extract the saturated styrene vapor, which was then combined with an additional air flow of 61 mL min−1. The resultant gas mixture, containing a styrene concentration of 1000 ppm and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 80,000 mL g−1 h−1, flowed onto the catalyst bed. Subsequently, the catalyst bed was heated from ambient temperature to 480 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. Gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014), equipped with a DB-Wax (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) capillary column and an FID detector, was employed to measure the concentrations of propane in both the inlet and outlet gases. Styrene conversion was calculated by following equation: X styrene = ( [ C ] in − [ C ] out ) / [ C ] in in which [C]in and [C]out represents the styrene concentration of inlet and outlet gas, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical and chemical properties Table 1 summaries general characterizations of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts with different Si/Al ratios (18, 40, 800 and 1200). According to N2 adsorption experiments, it is found that all these catalysts have a large specific surface area due to porous zeolites framework. CO chemisorption results indicate that the Pt dispersion in these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts significantly decreases with the increase of the Si/Al ratio. The mean sizes of Pt particles in the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The Pt@ZSM-5–18 catalyst with higher Si/Al ratio has larger Pt particles. For instance, the Pt@ZSM-5–18 catalyst shows the smallest Pt particle of 2.9 nm, whereas the Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalyst shows the largest Pt particle of 11.8 nm. The above results confirm that ZSM-5 with low Si/Al ratio benefits the dispersion of Pt, which is consistent with our previous work [23]. The Pt particle sizes in the TEM images (Fig. 1 ) were analyzed by particle size statistics. It can be seen that the average size of Pt particles obtained by particle size statistics is close to that obtained by CO chemisorption. This result indicates that the Pt particle size of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst prepared by the impregnation method indeed increases with the increase of the Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns and NH3-TPD profiles of the Pt@ZSM-5–18, Pt@ZSM-5–40, Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 7.84, 8.77, 11.78, 22.94, 23.18 and 24.39° are assigned to the MIF structure of ZSM-5 (JCPDS No. 42–0024) [24-26]. The characteristic diffraction peak corresponding to Pt species is absent in the XRD patterns, suggesting Pt species low content or well-dispersed in ZSM-5. The NH3-TPD profiles indicates the acid sites distribution on these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts. For the four catalysts, the Pt@ZSM-5–18 catalyst exhibits the highest relative surface acidity, while the relative surface acidity of Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 is similar to each other. Based on the NH3 desorption peak, it can be seen that the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with lower Si/Al has more acid sites. The desorption peak (α) centered at 150 °C is ascribed to the NH3 absorbed on weak sites for the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts. For the Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalyst, the desorption peak (labeled α) area remarkably increases compared to that of the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts, and a weak desorption peak (labeled β) centered at 450 °C is assigned to the moderate strong or strong acid sites [21]. The Pt@ZSM-5–18 catalyst exhibits larger desorption peak area of both peak (α) and peak (β), suggesting its more total amount of acid sites. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves were measured to characterize the porosity of these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts. It can be found that all the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts show the type IV isotherm curves with a remarkable hysteresis loop, confirming the abundant micro-mesoporous structure in the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts. The parameters regarding the porosity of these catalysts are also listed in the Table 1. It is found that the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with higher Si/Al ratio shows the lower surface area. To study the electron structure of Pt nanoparticles in these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts, the experiment of CO adsorption infrared spectra were conducted (Fig. 2d). The intense bands observed at 2000–2100 cm−1 are present in all of the catalysts, and they are attributed to CO linearly adsorbed on the Pt sites [23]. These bands exhibit a shift to lower wavenumbers for the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts with a low Si/Al ratio, indicating that Pt species in ZSM-5 with low Si/Al possess higher electron density. 3.2 Catalytic styrene oxidation Fig. 3 shows the light-off curves and the specific mass reaction rates (at 100 °C) for styrene complete oxidation over these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts. It can be found that the catalytic activity of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst firstly increases then decreases when Si/Al ratio increases from 18 to 1200 (Fig. 3a). The specific mass rate presents a volcanic curve change to the increase Pt particle size of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst for styrene oxidation (Fig. 3b). Among them, the Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalyst shows the highest catalytic activity, which exhibits a specific mass rate of 1.6 µmol gPt −1 s−1 at 100 °C. The Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalyst shows the lowest specific mass rate of 0.3 µmol gPt −1 s−1. The above results confirm that Pt particle size, affected by Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5, is closely related to the catalytic activity for styrene, the suitable small Pt particle (3.3 nm) benefits to styrene oxidation reaction. Carbon deposition often leads to serious deactivation of catalyst for VOCs elimination, particularly for zeolites based catalysts. Therefore, the stability of these catalysts has been evaluated at different reaction temperature as shown in Fig. 4 . It can be found that all these catalysts exhibits remarkable deactivation when reaction conducted at their T80 (the temperature of styrene conversion 80 %) in Fig. 4a. Such deactivation phenomenon was also observed at the temperature of T99+10 for all these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts (Fig. 4b). When the reaction temperature was further increased to T99+30, remarkable deactivation has still been found for the Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalysts (Fig. 4c). Whereas, the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts can remain stable activity at T99+30, indicating the high reaction temperature inhibits the catalyst deactivation. For the Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalysts, the deactivation still occurs when reaction temperature increases to their T99+50 (Fig. 4d). The Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalysts can remain high activity only when reaction temperature is further increased to T99+80 (Fig. 4e-f). The above results suggest that Si/Al ratio seriously affects the deactivation of Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst for styrene combustion, and the lower Si/Al ratio of Pt@ZSM-5, the higher operation need to inhibit the deactivation. 3.3 Deactivation mechanism In order to clearly reveal the deactivation mechanism for these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted for both the fresh and spent Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts (reaction at T80 for 10 h) (Fig. 5 ). Compared to the fresh catalyst, the additional weight loss of the spent Pt@ZSM-5 in TGA curve is ascribed to the carbon deposition during stryene oxidation. The additional weight loss order of these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts is Pt@ZSM-5–18 > Pt@ZSM-5–40 > Pt@ZSM-5–800 > Pt@ZSM-5–1200. Among them, the Pt@ZSM-5–18 catalyst shows the most additional weight loss of 5.63 %, suggesting its serious carbon deposition behavior. The Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalyst nearly shows no additional weight loss, representing less carbon deposition in Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalyst under same reaction condition. The images of these fresh and spent Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts are also collected as shown in Fig. 6 . It can be found that the spent Pt@ZSM-5–18 catalyst shows purple colour which is very different with its fresh catalyst. Similar result is also observed for the spent Pt@ZSM-5–40 and Pt@ZSM-5–800 catalysts. Interestingly, the spent Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalyst keeps the same colour to the fresh one, confirming not serious carbon deposition on the spent Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalyst. In order to further understand the styrene oxidation mechanism on catalyst surface, in situ FTIR spectra of styrene oxidation were conducted as shown in Fig. 7 . The related characteristic vibration peaks are assigned in the Table 2 . For the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst, it can be found that the skeletal υ(C=C) stretching vibrations of aromatic ring can be found at 1440, 1500 and 1593 cm−1, and the υ(C-H) stretching vibrations appear at 3091 and 3032 cm−1.[27] This result suggests styrene absorbed on the catalyst preparing to participate oxidation reaction. In addition, the characteristic vibration peaks of 1651, 1731, 2691, 2874 and 2925 cm−1 are ascribed to the C=O stretching vibration of benzaldehyde specie.[7,27] Then the benzaldehyde specie is further oxidized to benzoate specie as confirmed by the appearance of skeletal υ(C=C) stretching vibration. The characteristic vibration peaks of 1944 and 1950 cm−1 are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric υ(C=O) stretching vibrations of maleic anhydride, indicating the destruction of aromatic ring [28]. The characteristic vibration peaks of CO linearly adsorbed on Pt is found at 2082 cm−1 due to organic intermediate oxidized to CO [29]. Afterwards, CO adsorbed on Pt sites is further oxidized to CO2. The specific pathway of styrene oxidation on Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst has been proposed in the Scheme 1 . Besides, it can be found that the intensity of characteristic vibration peaks ascribed to intermediates gradually increases when reaction temperature increased for both Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40. This result suggests high reaction temperature promotes the styrene oxidation on catalyst surface, but the intermediates (benzaldehyde, maleic anhydride, etc.) remarkably accumulated on the catalyst surface. Whereas, the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts show relatively weak intensity of characteristic vibrations ascribed to those intermediates. In particularly, the characteristic vibrations of intermediates rapidly weaken when reaction temperature increased over 250 °C. The above result confirms that the Si/Al ratio of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst affects the intermediates accumulated on catalyst surface. 3.4 Water resistance of catalysts Considering that water vapor usually exists in the real exhaust gas and causes the serious deactivation of platinum-based catalysts due to the competitive adsorption of water vapor in active sites. Thus, the influence of water vapor on these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts for styrene oxidation was also conducted. The styrene oxidation reaction was carried out under staged reaction conditions (0.1 % styrene/Air balanced; 0.1 % styrene + 5 % H2O/Air balanced) to observe the effect of water. It can be found that the presence of water vapor (5 vol% H2O) leads to a slight decrease of catalytic activity for the Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalysts, whereas the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 shows very robust catalytic stability for styrene even under 5 vol% H2O condition. Such result suggests that the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with low Si/Al ratio is more sensitive to water vapor (5 vol% H2O) due to the significantly competitive adsorption of water vapor to reactant molecule, which is consistent with our previous work [23] (Fig. 8 ). 4 Conclusion In summary, the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts with different Si/Al ratio (18, 40, 800, 1200) were employed for styrene combustion. It is found that Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5 significantly affects the Pt particles size and the initial reaction rate of Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst for styrene combustion. The specific mass rate presents a volcanic curve change to the increase Pt particle size of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst for styrene oxidation. Moreover, serious deactivation was observed for all these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts at relatively low reaction temperature such as their T80. The deactivation of the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst is remarkably dependent on the Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5 catalyst. According to the detailed characterizations, it is found that the intermediates (benzaldehyde, maleic anhydride, etc.) of styrene oxidation easier accumulate on the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst surface with abundant surface acid sites (low Si/Al ratio). The Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts with low density of surface acid sites is responsible for the rapid removal of styrene oxidation intermediates. The deactivation of Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst will be inhibited by conducting the reaction at higher temperature. For instance, the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts remains stable activity when reaction was conducted at the T99 +30, whereas a much higher operation reaction temperature (T99 +80) is necessary to resist deactivation for the Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalysts. Besides, it is found that all these Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts exhibit very robust stabilities for styrene oxidation under water vapor (5 vol% H2O) condition, particularly for those catalysts with high Si/Al ratio. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidation plays a pivotal role in styrene elimination, yet the development of highly active and robust catalysts remains a challenge. This work aims to elucidate the mechanisms underlying styrene oxidation and catalyst deactivation over the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst. The Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with low Si/Al ratio and high surface acidity leads to generation of small Pt particle, the initial activity of the catalyst varies in a volcanic curve with the size of Pt particles. Notably, the Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalyst with Pt particle size of 3.3 nm exhibits the highest reaction rate of 1.6 µmol gPt −1 s−1 at 100 °C. However, the Pt@ZSM-5 catalysts undergo significant deactivation at their T80 (the temperature styrene conversion of 80 %). Through comprehensive characterizations and detailed mechanistic studies, it has been observed that intermediates from styrene oxidation accumulate heavily on the catalyst, especially for the Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst with high acidity. Improving the reaction temperature could inhibit the deactivation which is dependent on the surface acidity of Pt@ZSM-5 catalyst. For instance, the Pt@ZSM-5–800 and Pt@ZSM-5–1200 catalysts remains high activity when reaction is operated at T99+30, whereas a substantially higher reaction temperature (T99+80) is required for both Pt@ZSM-5–18 and Pt@ZSM-5–40 catalysts to counteract deactivation. Our primary results provide insights to develop effective and robust catalyst for styrene oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic styrene combustion over Pt/ZSM-5 Catalysts: Elucidating the deactivation mechanism induced by surface acid sites
